{{distinguish|Tehranno}} {{Infobox Korean name| img= | hangul={{linktext|테헤란|로}}| hanja=테헤란{{linktext|路}}| rr=Teheranro| mr=T'eheranno| }}
'''Teheranno''' (alternatively '''Teheran-ro''', translation "[[Tehran]] Boulevard") is a street in the [[Gangnam district]] of [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]]. It runs from [[Gangnam Station]] through [[Yeoksam-dong]] and into [[Samseong-dong]]. It is colloquially known as "'''Teheran Valley'''" (after [[Silicon Valley]]) due to the number of [[internet]]-related companies operating there. The district of [[Gangnam-gu]] experienced phenomenal growth and waves of construction, with Teheranno becoming one of the busiest streets in South Korea. Its counterpart, Seoul St. in [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] , runs in the north of that city, close to the [[Evin]] district.
Teheranno is a 3.5 km section of Korean Highway 90, and runs eastwards from [[Gangnam Station]] to [[Samseong Station]] and the [[COEX]]/[[KWTC]] complex. [[Yeoksam Station|Yeoksam]] and [[Seolleung Station|Seolleung]] stations are also on Teheranno. All stations are on [[Seoul Subway Line 2]].
Some of Korea's tallest skyscrapers and most expensive real estate are in Teheranno, while Seoul Metropolitan Government estimates that more than half of Korea's [[venture capital]], some 200,000,000,000 won (approximately $200,000,000), is invested in Teheran Valley.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.seoul.go.kr/business/indust/indust_05ven_02.html|title=Teheran Valley, Seoul Metropolitan Government|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040408214016/http://english.seoul.go.kr/business/indust/indust_05ven_02.html|archivedate=2004-04-08|df=}}</ref>
==Name== [[File:لوح یادبود خیابان تهران در سئول.JPG|thumb|250px|right|The tablet of commemorating the visit by [[Gholamreza Nikpey|Mr. Gholamreza Nikpay]], Tehran's Mayor, to Mr. Kuh Cha-chun, Seoul's Mayor]] On 27 June 1977, the Seoul Metropolitan Government suggested that the city of Seoul and [[Tehran]], pre-[[Iranian Revolution|revolutionary]] [[Pahlavi Dynasty|Iran]] exchange the names of streets on the [[Iran–South Korea relations|occasion of the visit]] to Korea of [[Gholamreza Nikpey]], [[Mayor of Tehran]]. The following year, Samneungno street was renamed Teheranno, which then ran through a relatively underdeveloped area that been annexed into Seoul in 1963.
==Economy== The area hosts major domestic [[internet portals]] [[Daum Communications|Daum]] and [[Naver]] as well as [[Google]]. [[Samsung Electronics]] and [[Hynix]] both operate offices there. Various Korean and international financial and business institutions including [[POSCO]], [[Standard Chartered]] and [[Citibank]] also maintain offices there.
The headquarters of [[LOEN Entertainment]], one of the largest music companies in the country, is located in Teheranno.

{{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=April 2015}} {{notability|date=April 2015}} {{Orphan|date=July 2016}} }} '''UIBS''' (short for '''US India Business Summit''') is an annual Business Expo between the [[United States|U.S.]] and India that is best known for its multidisciplinary speeches and panels, but is held only every other year. It is devoted to what it calls "Friendship and Business between the United States and India". The goal of UIBS is to promote business and investment between United States and India in key areas of technology, agriculture, healthcare, infrastructure, supply chain, logistics, real estate and investment etc. Our{{who|date=April 2015}} special emphasis is to connect entrepreneurs and small-to- medium size businesses. UIBS 2010 is organized by the [[Georgia Institute of Technology|Georgia Tech]] Center for International Business Education & Research (CIBER), USA India Initiatives, Inc. (USIII) and US India Business and Research Center (USIBRC) with support of [[Georgia Department of Economic Development]], the [[Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce]], US Commercial Services, and the [[US Department of Commerce]]. ==Background== UIBS 2010 is organized by Georgia Tech Center for International Business Education & Research (CIBER), USA India Initiatives, Inc. (USIII) and US India Business and Research Center (USIBRC) with support of [[Georgia Department of Economic Development]], the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, U.S. Commercial Service of [[United States of America]], [[Department of Commerce]]. The UIBS mission statement is:
The Goal of UIBS is to promote business and investment between USA and India in key areas of technology, agriculture, healthcare, infrastructure, supply chain, logistics, real estate and investment etc. Our special emphasis is to connect entrepreneurs and small-to- medium size businesses.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox radio station | name = WDCH-FM | image = File:WDCH Bloomberg99.1-105.7HD2 logo.png | city = [[Bowie, Maryland]] | area = [[Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area]] | branding = ''Bloomberg 99.1 and 105.7 HD2'' | slogan = "Wall Street Listens. The World Listens." | frequency = 99.1 [[Megahertz|MHz]] | translator = | repeater = 105.7-2 WJZ-HD2 (Baltimore) | airdate = [[1947 in radio|1947]] (as WNAV-FM) | share = | share as of = | share source = | format = [[Business news]] | power = | erp = 45,000 watts | haat = {{convert|157|meters}} | class = B | facility_id = 72177 | coordinates = {{coord|39|1|48|N|76|44|25|W|region:US-MD_type:landmark|name=WDCH-FM|display=inline,title}} | callsign_meaning = '''W'''ashington, '''D.C.''' H (placeholder) | former_callsigns = WNAV-FM (1947–1983)
WLOM-FM (1983)
WLOM (1983)
[[WHFS (historic)|WHFS]] (1983–2005)
WZLL (2005)
WLZL (2005–2011)
WNEW-FM (2011–2016) | affiliations = [[Westwood One News]]
[[Bloomberg Radio]]
[[Associated Press]]
[[WUSA (TV)|WUSA 9]] | operator = [[Bloomberg L.P.]] | owner = [[Entercom]] | licensee = Entercom License, LLC | sister_stations = [[WIAD]], [[WJFK-FM]], [[WLZL]], [[WJFK (AM)|WJFK]], [[WPGC-FM]], [[WJZ (AM)|WJZ]], [[WJZ-FM]], [[WLIF]], [[WWMX-FM]] | webcast = {{listenlive|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/radio/}} | website = {{URL|bloomberg.com/radio/}} }} '''WDCH-FM''' (99.1 [[FM broadcasting|FM]]) is a radio station currently broadcasting a [[business news]] format to the [[Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area|Baltimore, Maryland/Washington, D.C. metropolitan area]]. Licensed to [[Bowie, Maryland]] the station is currently owned by [[Entercom]] and operated by [[Bloomberg L.P.]] Its transmitter is located near [[Crofton, Maryland]], and the broadcasting studios are located near the [[Washington Navy Yard]] along the north/west bank of the [[Anacostia River]] (Eastern Branch of the [[Potomac River]]) in [[Southeast, Washington, D.C.|Southeast Washington]]. WDCH is one of the few stations in the Baltimore/Washington corridor that directly targets ''both'' markets. This is because its transmitter is located halfway between the two cities, providing a strong city-grade signal to both. WDCH-FM often airs [[D.C. United]] soccer and [[Washington Wizards]] pro [[basketball]] games in the [[NBA]] whenever sister station [[WJFK-FM]] (106.7 "The Fan") is already covering a game elsewhere. ==History== {{see also|WHFS (historic)}} The 99.1 MHz frequency was originally '''WNAV-FM''', licensed to [[Annapolis, Maryland]] and featuring a [[beautiful music]] format. It competed with similar stations in both the Baltimore and Washington markets. In 1983, the station changed calls to '''WLOM-FM'''. In 1983 the owners of WHFS, then licensed to [[Bethesda, Maryland|Bethesda]] at 102.3 FM, sold that station for $2 million and used the money to purchase WLOM along with and its sister station [[WNAV]] (1430 AM). The '''WHFS''' format and call letters were then moved to 99.1 FM, licensed to operate with 50,000 watts ([[list of broadcast station classes|Class B FM]]) with much higher power than the 102.3 facility, which broadcasts with only 3,000 watts (Class A) at the time; a Class A FM is the lowest coverage area as opposed to a [[list of broadcast station classes|Class A]] AM which is the greatest coverage area. Thus WHFS on 99.1 could then be heard in Baltimore, Washington, and much of the [[Eastern Shore of Maryland]]. Eventually Einstein's group sold WHFS. When the station switched formats, it was located at the [[Infinity Broadcasting Corporation|Infinity Broadcasting]] Center in [[Lanham, Maryland]]. The 102.3 frequency is now occupied by an Urban AC station in Washington, using the call letters [[WMMJ]] and nicknamed "Majic 102.3". {{see also|HFStival}} Since 1990, WHFS has hosted an event called the HFStival, an annual (sometimes semi-annual) day-long (sometimes two-day-long) outdoor concert. The concert, often held at Washington's [[RFK Stadium]], features a variety local and national acts; for example, the 2004 lineup included [[The Cure]], [[Jay-Z]], [[Modest Mouse]], the [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs]], and [[Cypress Hill]]. Robert Benjamin, Bob Waugh and Bill Glasser took the HFStival from a small yearly concert in Fairfax, Virginia, to a large festival in Washington, D.C. that was headlined by major acts and was surrounded by culturally significant booths, games, food, and rides, as well as an outdoor second stage. Amongst others, [[Billy Zero]] was instrumental in growing the [[HFStival]] Locals Only Stage where bands like [[Good Charlotte]] and [[Jimmie's Chicken Shack]] got their big break. The term Locals Only stuck and is still used today and the Locals Only Stage was copied by Modern Rock Stations across the Country. In the mid-1990s, Liberty Broadcasting published a quarterly magazine titled "WHFS Press" that was mailed to listeners and available in local music outlets."WHFS Press", Liberty Broadcasting, Winter 1994 Though becoming famous as a cutting-edge station playing the latest underground music (and often beating the mainstream to the punch by months and even years), under Infinity Broadcasting's [[ownership]], the station became the local modern alternative rock station in the mid 90s. No longer playing rather obscure progressive rock, nor the classic and hard rock of its Baltimore competitor [[WIYY]], HFS was now formatted more towards a younger set of fans who were more apt to listen to [[Green Day]] and Fuel than less mainstream artists such as [[Fugazi]] or [[Lou Reed]]. The station played much of the alternative hits that were touted by the mainstream press and MTV, turning off many old-school HFS listeners, but in turn gaining many listeners in the 18–24 age demographic. During this period, WHFS featured a specialty show called "Now Hear This", hosted by Dave Marsh, which highlighted indie and local music. The station never fully reverted to its prior all-indie status, but it did begin to combine more underground programming with its modern rock format. In 1999, WHFS released a New Music New Video Compilation Volume 1 on VHS that was distributed free at Washington area [[Tower Records]] outlets. It featured tracks by [[Cyclefly]], [[Fuel (band)|Fuel]], [[Fastball (band)|Fastball]], [[Elliott Smith]], [[Kid Rock]], [[Eve 6]], [[3 Colours Red]], [[Puya (band)|Puya]], and [[Joydrop]]. ==="El Zol 99.1 FM"=== At noon on January 12, 2005, 99.1 switched to a [[Tropical (radio format)|Tropical]] Latin music format. Its call letters were changed to '''WZLL''' on January 28, 2005, and then again to '''WLZL''' on February 5, 2005, and the station was rebranded as "El Zol 99.1 FM". [[AOL]], which had a partnership with Infinity Broadcasting and recognized that many people would miss the old WHFS format, quickly launched an internet-only streaming radio station with a playlist much like that of WHFS.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7886-2005Jan13.html WHFS: For Many, The Only Alternative] Due to numerous complaints about the format change, which attracted media attention, then-owner Infinity brought the WHFS format back a month later on the 105.7 FM frequency (now [[WJZ-FM]]). The WHFS call letters have since relocated first to a talk station on 1580 AM (now [[WJFK (AM)|WJFK]]), then to [[WUUB|a sister station]] in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]]. WLZL was also [[CBS Radio]]'s first Spanish radio station, and the company's only Spanish station outside the southern United States. [[Image:Chevrolet Equinox -- 02-14-2012.jpg|thumb|right|A WNEW [[Chevrolet Equinox]] news vehicle]] On November 16, 2011, CBS Radio announced plans to acquire WFSI (107.9 MHz) from religious broadcaster [[Family Radio]], with the intention of moving WLZL's Spanish Tropical format and ''"El Zol"'' branding from 99.1 to 107.9, with a new [[News radio|all-news]] format launched on 99.1 FM to compete directly with the region's leading all-news format station, long-time powerhouse [[WTOP-FM]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.radio-info.com/news/official-cbs-buying-dc-baltimore-wfsi-1079-will-debut-all-news-on-991 |title=Radio-Info: "Official: CBS buying D.C.-Baltimore WFSI (107.9), will debut all-news on 99.1", November 16, 2011. |access-date=November 17, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120012948/http://www.radio-info.com/news/official-cbs-buying-dc-baltimore-wfsi-1079-will-debut-all-news-on-991 |archive-date=November 20, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}[http://www.cbsradio.com/press_center/releases/pressrelease145027-11-16-2011.html CBS Radio press release: "CBS RADIO TO BRING ALL-NEWS STATION TO 99.1 FM IN WASHINGTON, D.C.", November 16, 2011.] The 99.1 MHz frequency then adopted the '''WNEW-FM''' call sign, which was named after the former [[WBBR|AM]] and [[WNEW-FM|FM]] stations of the same name in New York City. [http://radioinsight.com/blog/headlines/54356/cbs-acquires-wfsi-to-launch-all-news-on-99-1/ Radio Insight: "CBS Acquires WFSI, To Launch All-News On 99.1", November 20, 2011] (updated January 22, 2012) The format change occurred on December 1, when 99.1 and 107.9 both began simulcasting El Zol. El Zol was finally moved to 107.9 on December 12, 2011, and 99.1 began [[Stunting (broadcasting)|stunting]] with [[Christmas music]], with the '''WNEW-FM''' call letters now in place on 99.1. On December 27, 2011, WNEW-FM ended its Christmas music stunting and began stunting with the 1981 Silver Anniversary Edition of ''[[The History of Rock and Roll]]''. ===All News 99.1=== [[File:WNEW991.png|thumb|Logo as All News 99.1, 2012–15]] The all-news format launched at noon on January 22, 2012; the station initially planned to launch at 5 a.m. on January 19,{{cite news|title=CBS Radio's "All News 99.1" WNEW to debut in Washington, D.C. on Thursday, 1/19|url=http://www.radio-info.com/news/cbs-radios-all-news-991-wnew-to-debut-in-washington-dc-on-thursday-119|accessdate=January 3, 2012|newspaper=Radio-Info.com|date=January 3, 2012}} but postponed it due to technical problems.{{cite news|title=CBS delays the launch of Washington DC's "News 99.1"|url=http://www.radio-info.com/news/cbs-delays-the-launch-of-washington-dcs-news-991|accessdate=January 18, 2012|newspaper=Radio-Info.com|date=January 17, 2012}} The station also broadcasts simultaneously in [[HD Radio]] on [[WIAD|94.7 FM – HD2]] and [[WJZ-FM|105.7 FM – HD2]]. WNEW-FM regularly programmed traffic reports and weather every five minutes between 5 am and 7 pm on the ones and sixes weekdays, and every ten minutes on the ones (six times an hour) the rest of the week (both from CBS local affiliate television station [[WUSA (TV)|WUSA]], Channel 9), sports updates twice an hour at :25 and :55 from sister all-sports station [[WJFK-FM]], entertainment news once an hour, and business news from [[Bloomberg News]] twice an hour at :15 and :45. When breaking news warranted, WNEW-FM would break format to provide continuous coverage of any event. When the station began, it had traffic reports only every ten minutes, and had weather reports every four minutes. At the beginning, it focused on Washington area news, traffic, and weather. In 2014, the station expanded its coverage of the [[Baltimore metropolitan area]] by providing news, traffic and weather reports, and coordinated with on-air personalities in the news, sports and weather departments from its long-time market-leading station [[WJZ-TV]]; the change was widely promoted and advertised at the time. This was thought to be an opportune time, since competitor [[WFED|WTOP]] had switched from its long-time wide-ranging AM signal at 1500, to several FM repeaters which curtailed its traditionally strong signal across two states and the District. WNEW-FM was now the only station to provide coverage to ''both'' [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] and [[Baltimore]], unlike WTOP, which had, since the early 1970s, focused on the Washington area and only occasionally carried Baltimore news events, sports or the slightly different weather and temperature readings. As done with other CBS-owned all-news stations, WNEW-FM provided the audio feed of such network news programming as the daily ''[[CBS Evening News]]'' each weeknight at 7 pm, Sunday's ''[[Face the Nation]]'' interview/discussion program, and the weekly Sunday news magazine, ''[[60 Minutes]]''; the latter's simulcast was frequently promoted by WJZ-TV, but the radio broadcast was paused every 10 minutes for traffic and weather updates, and as a result, the WNEW-FM simulcast would be a few minutes behind the CBS television broadcast. In addition, similar to other CBS-owned all-news stations, ''60 Minutes'' was broadcast at 7 pm on Sundays each and every week, regardless of whether or not the televised version (usually an [[National Football League|NFL]] football game) was delayed on CBS. ===99.1 WNEW=== On February 23, 2015, WNEW-FM began airing [[Talk radio|Talk]] programs, including the syndicated [[The Dave Ramsey Show (radio program)|The Dave Ramsey Show]] in the evenings, a business and personal finance call-in program {{cite web |url=http://www.radioink.com/article.asp?id=2898324&spid=24698 |title=Radio Ink Magazine |publisher=Radio Ink Magazine }} and [[Overnight America]], another syndicated nationwide late-night broadcast. {{cite web |url=http://radioinsight.com/blog/headlines/92089/wnew-adds-dave-ramsey/ |title=RadioInsight – WNEW Adds Dave Ramsey |publisher=RadioInsight }} On the first weekend in March 2015, media insider local internet news website dcrtv.com reported that CBS Radio was moving their DC-area radio stations studios and offices closer to [[Nationals Park]], which is the home of the local baseball team, the [[Washington Nationals]]. WNEW-FM was the first station to move. On March 8, 2015, WNEW-FM claimed that they were renovating their studios and could not continue broadcasting their ordinary news programming, promising to return to regular programming later that night. This came weeks after hosts on sister station [[WJFK-FM|WJFK-FM, 106.7, "The Fan"]] had similar problems. ===Bloomberg 99-1=== On December 18, 2015, at 10 am, WNEW-FM began simulcasting [[Bloomberg Radio]] as "Bloomberg 99.1 & 105.7-HD2" after CBS began leasing the station to Bloomberg earlier that day.https://radioinsight.com/blog/headlines/95575/dc-all-news-battle-comes-to-end-as-cbs-sells-99-1-wnew/http://formatchange.com/wnew-becomes-bloomberg-99-1/ WIAD-HD2 would drop the WNEW simulcast and flip to [[classic hits]] a couple months later in February. On March 15, 2016, WNEW-FM changed calls to '''WDCH-FM'''. The WNEW-FM call letters returned to New York City that same day.https://radioinsight.com/blog/headlines/105426/wnew-fm-call-letters-return-to-102-7-new-york/ On February 2, 2017, CBS Radio announced it would merge with [[Entercom]].[https://radioinsight.com/headlines/116299/cbs-radio-to-merge-with-entercom/ CBS Radio to Merge with Entercom] The merger was approved on November 9, 2017, and was consummated on the 17th.{{cite web|url=http://entercom.com/press/entercom-receives-fcc-approval-merger-cbs-radio/|title=Entercom Receives FCC Approval for Merger with CBS Radio|work=Entercom|date=November 9, 2017|accessdate=November 17, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://radioinsight.com/headlines/121072/entercom-completes-cbs-radio-merger/|title=Entercom Completes CBS Radio Merger|last=Venta|first=Lance|work=Radio Insight|date=November 17, 2017|accessdate=November 17, 2017}} Despite the merger, Bloomberg will continue to lease the station via a [[time brokerage agreement]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Radio|Washington, D.C.}} *[[WTOP-FM]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{FM station data|WDCH}} {{Bloomberg Radio}} {{Washington Radio}} {{Baltimore Radio}} {{News/Talk Radio Stations in Maryland}} {{Entercom}} [[Category:Radio stations in Baltimore|DCH-FM]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1947]] [[Category:1947 establishments in Maryland]] [[Category:Entercom radio stations]] [[Category:Business talk radio stations]] [[Category:Business media in the United States]]

'''The Whistle blower Week''' is the name given to a series of events in Washington, D.C. meant to raise awareness about [[whistleblower|whistle blowing]]. There were two whistle blower weeks which took place in Washington in two different years.
The first Whistle blower Week took place in Washington, D.C. from May 13–19, 2007 and was sponsored by a loose coalition of whistle blower-related advocacy groups. The week was timed to coincide with the fifth anniversary of the May 15, 2002 enactment of the "Notification and Federal Employee Anti-discrimination and Retaliation Act of 2002" (Public Law 107-174), now known as the [[No-FEAR Act]].<ref name="federal">{{cite web |url=http://federaltimes.com/index.php?S=2744160 |title=First Whistleblower Week in Washington begins Sunday |author=Tim Kauffman |publisher=federaltimes.com |date=May 11, 2007 |accessdate=July 15, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130123194012/http://federaltimes.com/index.php?S=2744160 |archivedate=January 23, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} </ref> During the week, whistle blowers and their allies gathered for awards ceremonies, speeches, panel discussions, and training sessions. The 2007 event was featured in the ''[[New York Times]]''<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/18/washington/18whistleblower.htm?_r=1&oref=slogin |title=From Out of the Shadows, Whistle-Blowers Convene |author=Scott Shane |work=The New York Times |date=May 18, 2007 |accessdate=October 27, 2007}}</ref> and announced in the [[Congressional Record]] by Republican Senator [[Chuck Grassley|Charles Grassley]] of Iowa.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/record.xpd?id=110-s20070514-9#sMonofilemx003Ammx002Fmmx002Fmmx002Fmhomemx002Fmgovtrackmx002Fmdatamx002Fmusmx002Fm110mx002Fmcrmx002Fms20070514-9.xmlElementm0m0m0m |title=WHISTLEBLOWER WEEK IN WASHINGTON |author=Senator Charles Grassley |publisher=Congressional Record |date=May 14, 2007 |accessdate=January 10, 2010}}</ref>
The second Whistle blower Week took place May 12–15, 2008 and was sponsored by the No Fear Coalition, the [[Semmelweis Society]], and the Bill of Rights Foundation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whistleblower.org/content/press_detail.cfm?press_id=1367 |title=GAP Whistleblower Week Events Kick Off Monday |publisher=[[Government Accountability Project]] |date=May 8, 2008 |accessdate=October 1, 2010}}</ref>
==2007 Week events and participants== The first Whistle blower Week was organized by around fifty organizations<ref name="federal" /> and included a diverse group of participants, from a United States Senator to a 9–11 conspiracy theorist recruiting followers.<ref name="nytimes" /> Their main objective was to address issues about whistle blowing and more than forty public interests were addressed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ipsdc.org/events/washington_whistleblower_week|title=Washington Whistleblower Week - IPS|newspaper=Institute for Policy Studies|access-date=2017-02-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
Notable attendees included:
*Senator [[Chuck Grassley]], who received a lifetime achievement award from the [[National Whistleblower Center]] for his fight against waste, fraud and corruption in government. *[[Jeffrey Wigand]], a former tobacco executive who reported the industry's manipulation of nicotine levels in cigarettes and was featured in the movie ''[[The Insider (film)|The Insider]]''. *[[Coleen Rowley]], who blew the whistle on the [[FBI]]'s negligence preceding the September 11 terrorist attack. Ms. Rowley was named as one of ''[[Time Magazine]]'''s Persons of the Year, along with conference supporter and [[Enron]] whistleblower [[Sherron Watkins]]. The FBI Oversight Panel was led by former FBI Special Agents Rowley and Mike German. * Janet Howard, Joyce E. Megginson and [[[https://tanyawardjordan.com Tanya Ward Jordan]]], members of the No FEAR Coalition and class agents who blew the whistle on race discrimination at the Department of Commerce (Janet Howard, et al. vs Department of Commerce). *[[Bogdan Dzakovic]], former Federal Aviation Administration terrorism expert.<ref name="federal"/> *Dr. Marsha Coleman-Adebayo, an EPA employee who won a racial and gender discrimination lawsuit after alleging that a United States company was exposing South African miners and their families to toxic levels of [[vanadium]].<ref name="post">{{cite news |title=Coming Soon: A Tale of Whistleblowing at the EPA |author=Fears, D. |newspaper=Washington Post |date=July 10, 2006 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/09/AR2006070900741_pf.html}}</ref> *Bunnatine H. Greenhouse, of the Army Corps of Engineers. Greenhouse opposed the process that awarded government contracts to Halliburton, Inc., without counterbids.<ref name="nytimes"/> *[[Stephen M. Kohn]], Co-founder and Executive Director of the [[National Whistleblower Center]] hosted a series of workshops to aid whistleblowers and their lawyers. Kohn reminded participants that they stand to gain monetarily from whistleblowing activities.<ref name="nytimes"/>
==2008 participants== *[[Adam Kokesh]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ips-dc.org/events/339 |title=Washington Whistleblower Week |publisher=[[Institute for Policy Studies]] |accessdate=October 1, 2010}}</ref> *Reverend Lennox Yearwood, Jr. *Senator Charles Grassley *Congresswoman [[Sheila Jackson Lee]] of Texas *Congressman [[Jim Clyburn|James Clyburn]] of South Carolina

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Yevgeny Alexandrovich Chichvarkin |native_name = Евгений Александрович Чичваркин |image = Чичиваркин единая россия.jpg |caption = Yevgeny Chichvarkin, 14 April 2008 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|09|10|df=yes}} |birth_place = Moscow, [[Soviet Union]] |death_date = |death_place = |website = }} '''Yevgeny Alexandrovich Chichvarkin''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Евге́ний Алекса́ндрович Чичва́ркин}}; born 10 September 1974 in Moscow) is a Russian entrepreneur who founded the largest Russian mobile phone retailer, [[Yevroset]]. Due to this business, he became the richest man under 35 of his country, with an approximatively $1.6 billion wealth.
He has received a number of public awards including 2004 Person of the Year in the Head of Retail Business category. The winner of the Ernst & Young contest "Entrepreneur of the Year 2005" in the Nomination "Trade".<ref>https://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=297670</ref>
In 2006 Yevgeny Alexandrovich Chichvarkin was awarded the Order of St. Alexander Nevsky "For Labor and the Fatherland" in the nomination "Industry Leader". In 2006 was awarded the Order of Glory of Russia for his great personal contribution to the development of the best traditions of Russian entrepreneurship. In 2007, at the Grand Prix of the "Person of the Year 2006" Chichvarkin was awarded the Order of Glory of the Fatherland.<ref>http://www.r-o-g.ru/ru/news/master-klass-evgeniya-chichvarkina-7484/</ref>
He was a member of the [[Right Cause (political party)|Right Cause]] political party and was expected to become chairman of its Moscow section. Chichvarkin currently lives in London, from where he has campaigned against corruption in Russia and president [[Vladimir Putin]] personally.<ref name="Lentapedia">[http://www.lenta.ru/lib/14188567/ Евгений Чичваркин] collection of press-materials by [[Lenta.ru]] {{ru icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-whiz-kid-billionaire-who-says-he-cant-go-home-2038006.html |location=London |work=The Independent | title=The whiz kid billionaire who says he can't go home | date=29 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://chich8.livejournal.com/13758.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820101344/http://chich8.livejournal.com/13758.html |archivedate=20 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c8d99926-9d8d-11df-a37c-00144feab49a.html#axzz1TfY9B25y</ref>
On August 2012 he launched his new wine store Hedonism Wines on London's Davies Street.<ref>[http://www.in2up.com/startup-of-the-week/yevgeny-chichvarkin-hedonism-wines-in-the-business-of-wine-retailing/ "Yevgegy Chichvarkin, Hedonism Wines: In the business of wine retailing"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102104008/http://www.in2up.com/startup-of-the-week/yevgeny-chichvarkin-hedonism-wines-in-the-business-of-wine-retailing/ |date=2 November 2012 }}, ''[[In2up]]'', 28 September 2012. Retrieved on 28 November 2012.</ref>
==Biography== Chichvarkin was born in Saint-Petersburg, former Leningrad, USSR, from mother Lyudmila of Russian tatar descent and father Aleksandr from Moscow. His father was a pilot and his mother was an economist working for the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Trade; during his childhood, the family moved to Moscow.<ref name=Lentapedia/>
From 1991 to 1996 Chichvarkin studied at the [[The State University of Management|State Academy of Management]], as well as earning money trading on Moscow flea markets. After graduating Chichvarkin started studying for a PhD ([[Kandidat]]), which he abandoned in 1998.
==Yevroset Company== In 1997 Chichvarkin and his friend Timur Artemiev started a business named Yevroset<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=26381840|title=Yevroset}}</ref> to sell mobile phones. In 2002 Yevroset became one of the top three Moscow mobile phone retailers, with 92 retail outlets. The company opened 100 more outlets in 2002, 117 more outlets in 2003, 800 more outlets in 2004, 1934 more outlets in 2005, etc. In 2007 they had 5156 outlets in 12 countries: Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, Moldova, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Armenia and Azerbaijan.<ref name=Lentapedia/>
In June 2005, Yevroset has received the "Superbrand-2005" public award, in October 2005 "Brand of the Year / EFFIE 2005" awards and in December 2005 "The Company of the Year" in the nomination "Business Reputation". Yevroset is holders of the Diploma of the Russian Foundation for the Protection of Consumer Rights.<ref>https://ria.ru/society/20090311/164457497.html</ref>
September 21, 2008 Evgeny Chichvarkin sold "Euroset" to Alexander Mamut, the owner of investment company ANN and internet portal "Live Journal". <ref>https://dni.ru/economy/2008/9/22/149532.html</ref>
==Right Cause political party== In November 2008 Chichvarkin jointed [[Right Cause (political party)|Right Cause]], a Russian [[liberal democracy|liberal democratic]] [[list of political parties in Russia|political party]] founded on 16 November 2008 as a merger of the [[Union of Right Forces]], [[Civilian Power]] and the [[Democratic Party of Russia]].
==Criminal prosecution== In August 2005 Chichvarkin was accused of involvement in the illegal import of a $100 million shipment of mobile phones, but the accusations were eventually dropped. In March 2006 a large consignment of [[Motorola]] mobile phones shipped for Chichvarkin was seized on the pretext that their emissions of [[microwave radiation]] exceeded the levels permitted by Russian health regulations. After those cases Chichvarkin accused Russian law-enforcement agencies of [[corporate raid]]ing.<ref>[http://www.og.ru/news/2009/01/23/42694.shtml Экс-владелец «Евросети» Евгений Чичваркин объявлен в розыск] [[Obshchaya Gazeta]] 23 January 2009 {{ru icon}}</ref>
In March 2007 Chichvarkin was mentioned by the media in connection with the case of Dmitry Sidorov, the founder ''Iled M'', which was accused of large scale tax avoidance. Iled M had sold mobile phones to Yevroset as well as to other retailers. In August 2007 the apartments of many Yevroset employees were searched by police.<ref name=Lentapedia/> Some experts considered the searches to be connected with the Idel M case, while other saw it as a continuation of Motorola case. Others still viewed it as a marketing ploy by Yevroset themselves (the last chance to buy their phones before they are confiscated), others as a [[silovik]]s' revenge on Chichvarkin.<ref name=Lentapedia/>
In September 2008 the headquarters of Yevroset were searched in connection with its handling of Andrey Vlaskin, a Yevroset employee who in 2003 stole mobile phones worth around 20 million [[Russian rouble]]s (approximately US$1 million). Vlaskin was caught by Yevroset security in [[Tambov]], moved to Moscow to a Yevroset-owned apartment and after some time agreed to compensate Yevroset for their losses. While between 2004 and 2007 Yevroset and Vlaskin apparently had no claims on each other, in 2008 Yevroset was accused of kidnapping, illegal imprisonment and extortion.
On 21 September 2008 Chichvarkin sold 100% of Yevroset stock to [[Alexander Mamut]].<ref name=Lentapedia/> The volume of the transaction was US$400 million.<ref name=Lentapedia/>
In January 2009 Chichvarkin moved to the United Kingdom and on 23 January 2009 on Russian federal search list in connection with the Vlaskin case.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/27/russia-kremlin-oligarchs |location=London |work=The Guardian | first=Luke | last=Harding | title=Mobile phone oligarch flees Russia for new life in Britain | date=27 January 2009}}</ref> On 28 January the Basmanny Court of Moscow approved Chichvarkin's arrest ([[trial in absentia|''in absentia'']]).<ref name=Lentapedia/> On 12 March 2009 his details were passed to [[Interpol]].<ref name=interpol>{{cite news |first=Vladislav |last=Trifonov |title=Евгения Чичваркина передали Интерполу |url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?docsid=1136809 |publisher=[[Kommersant]] |date=12 March 2009 |accessdate=18 March 2009 }} </ref> On 13 April 2009 the Investigative Committee of the [[Prosecutor General of Russia]] noticed that a key investigator of Chichvarkin's case, Vladimir Knyazyev, had previously been sentenced for stealing a large consignment of mobile phones from Chichvarkin's Yevroset. During the 2007 contraband case he had forged the act of destroying the phones confiscated as evidence. The investigation committee demanded the dismissal of Knyazyev because of the conflict of interest but their demands were refused.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vremya.ru/2009/62/46/227040.html|script-title=ru:Мобильные споры|last=Karacheva|first=Yekaterina|date=13 April 2009|work=Vremya Novostey N62|language=Russian|accessdate=13 April 2009}}</ref> On 17 November 2010 the jury found all the defendants in the Vlaskin case not guilty.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|url=http://rian.ru/justice/20101117/297501879.html|title=Фигуранты дела "Евросети" не виновны в похищении человека – присяжные|accessdate=21 January 2011}}</ref>
The prosecution's appeal to the Supreme Court was rejected on 20 January 2011<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|url=http://rian.ru/justice/20110120/324058316.html|title=Оправдательный приговор по делу "Евросети" вступил в силу|accessdate=21 January 2011}}</ref> and Chichvarkin's indictment was withdrawn a few days later.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|url=http://www.rian.ru/inquest/20110124/325645010.html|title=СК РФ прекратил уголовное преследование Чичваркина|accessdate=24 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/26/uk-russia-tycoon-idUKTRE70P5YC20110126 | work=Reuters | title=Tycoon says Russia drops criminal charges | date=26 January 2011}}</ref>
His lawyer Yuri Gervis noted that Chichvarkin is still worried that he might be charged again in connection with the 2005 contraband case.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|url=http://www.infosud.ru/incident_news/20110124/251683421.html|script-title=ru:Чичваркин опасается быть привлеченным по делу от 2005 года – адвокат|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=24 January 2011|language=Russian}}</ref>
International search of Euroset Evgeny Chichvarkin has been discontinued. As reported on 25 January 2011 by an official representative of the National Central Bureau (NCB) of Interpol at the Interior Ministry Olga Shklyarov, it is due to the termination of criminal proceedings against Chichvarkin under Article 24 of the Code (the absence of a crime).<ref>http://www.newsru.com/russia/25jan2011/chichfree.html</ref>
While in London Chichvarkin has participated in protests highlighting the dangers of conducting business in Russia, referring to the cases of [[Mikhail Khodorkovsky]] and [[Sergei Magnitsky]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/01/idUSLDE7501VC20110601 | work=Reuters | title=Russian ex-tycoon protests outside London forum | date=1 June 2011}}</ref> He is aware of being observed by "men with russian behaviour".<ref>[https://www.novayagazeta.ru/news/2018/03/13/140135-chichvarkin-rasskazal-o-slezhke-za-nim-posle-pereezda-v-london Chichvarkin told about being watched after moving to London], Novaya Gazeta, March 13th 2018</ref>
==Hedonism Wines== On August 2012 Yevgeny Alexandrovich Chichvarkin launched his new wine store Hedonism Wines on London's Davies Street.<ref>[http://www.in2up.com/startup-of-the-week/yevgeny-chichvarkin-hedonism-wines-in-the-business-of-wine-retailing/ "Yevgegy Chichvarkin, Hedonism Wines: In the business of wine retailing"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102104008/http://www.in2up.com/startup-of-the-week/yevgeny-chichvarkin-hedonism-wines-in-the-business-of-wine-retailing/ |date=2 November 2012 }}, ''[[In2up]]'', 28 September 2012. Retrieved on 28 November 2012.</ref>
Hedonism Wines has received a number of public awards including Wine Merchant of the 2013 Year at the DWWA 2013 <ref>http://www.decanter.com/decanter-world-wine-awards/latest-coverage/dwwa-2013-london-wine-merchant-of-the-year-hedonism-wines-15979/</ref>, Best Leisure Food and Drink Shop at the Retail Week Interiors Awards 2014<ref>https://interiorsawards.retail-week.com/2014-winners</ref>, Best Speciality Food and Beverage Store 2014 at The Mayfair Awards 2014<ref>https://interiorsawards.retail-week.com/2014-winners</ref>, Independent Retailer of the Year at the DB AWARDS 2015<ref>https://www.thedrinksbusiness.com/2015/05/db-award-winners-announced/6/</ref>, Best Leisure Food and Drink Shop of the Year at the Retail Week Interiors Awards 2015<ref>https://interiorsawards.retail-week.com/shortlist-2015</ref>, Independent Wine Retailer of the Year 2015 at the 2015 Drinks Retailing Awards<ref>http://www.drinksretailingawards.co.uk/previous-winners</ref>, Best Speciality Food and Beverage Store 2015 at The Mayfair Awards 2015<ref>https://www.themayfairawards.co.uk/winners</ref>, Independent Spirits Retailer of the Year at the 2018 Drinks Retailing Awards<ref>http://www.drinksretailingawards.co.uk/previous-winners</ref>, Best Window Display 2017 at The Mayfair Awards 2017<ref>https://www.themayfairawards.co.uk/winners</ref>, Luxury Retailer of the Year at the 2017 Drinks Retailing Awards<ref>http://www.drinksretailingawards.co.uk/previous-winners</ref>, Luxury Retailer of the Year at the 2018 Drinks Retailing Awards<ref>http://www.drinksretailingawards.co.uk/</ref>.
